importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The AWS outage occurred on October 20, 2025, at approximately 07:11 GMT, marking a pivotal moment in the global tech infrastructure when widespread online services failed due to a technical error in AWS's systems.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The outage lasted from 07:11 to 10:11 GMT, highlighting a critical period during which over 113 AWS services were disrupted, affecting global digital services and user access to essential tools.

keyTakeAways: The AWS outage was caused by a technical error in a software update to DynamoDB’s API, which triggered a failure in the Domain Name System (DNS), preventing apps from finding the correct server addresses.

The failure propagated across AWS's infrastructure, affecting 113 services and disrupting major platforms including Snapchat, Pinterest, Roblox, Fortnite, WhatsApp, Zoom, Slack, Starbucks, Duolingo, Canva, and financial apps like Venmo.
The root cause was identified as human error during a routine update, not a cyberattack or malicious activity, as confirmed by cybersecurity experts.
AWS responded swiftly, deploying multiple recovery paths and restoring all services by 10:11 GMT, though some users experienced message backlogs and delays.
The incident underscores the critical dependence of modern digital life on cloud infrastructure, with AWS serving as the dominant provider of cloud computing services globally.
Despite the scale of disruption, experts believe the impact was contained due to AWS’s market dominance and deep integration with other companies’ digital operations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: An AWS cloud outage that began at 07:11 GMT on October 20, 2025, in Virginia, was caused by a software update error to DynamoDB’s API, which disrupted the Domain Name System (DNS) and prevented apps from connecting to servers. This led to a cascading failure affecting 113 AWS services, including major platforms such as Snapchat, Roblox, WhatsApp, Zoom, and financial services like Venmo and Coinbase. The outage impacted a wide range of services—from social media and gaming to banking, media, and smart home devices—demonstrating the deep interdependence of modern digital life on cloud infrastructure. AWS responded swiftly, restoring all services by 10:11 GMT, though some users faced message backlogs. Experts confirmed the incident stemmed from human error, not a cyberattack, emphasizing that while such outages are not rare, their global impact underscores the critical role of cloud providers like AWS in supporting the digital economy.
title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?
